We often hear Cache invalidation is a hard problem in computer science and could cause bugs but sometimes, caching something that should not be cached is a potential source of bugs and security vulnerabilities. Rails has a built-in mechanism for Fragment Caching, which stores part of the rendered view as a fragment. For subsequent requests, the pre-saved fragment is used instead of rendering it again.

But this could cause some serious bugs for example, we could have an s3 URL helper which generates a unique presigned URL for each of the product or one could write a form helper that outputs a request-specific auth token, in such cases, it is better to avoid Fragment Caching.

Before

Using the cache helper we can implement fragment caching.

views/products/index.html.erb

{% highlight ruby %}

<tbody>
    <% @products.each do |product| %>
      <% cache(product) do %>
          <%= render product %>
      <% end %>
    <% end %>
</tbody>
Title Description Image
{% endhighlight %}

views/products/_product.html.erb

{% highlight ruby %}

<%= product.title %> <%= product.description %> <%= image_tag(generate_presigned_url(product.image_url)) %> {% endhighlight %}

But, here is a bug because, we get a cached version of the product each time we are rendering the products though, we are generating the unique presigned URL each time. To resolve the above issue, we need to include cacheable in the Product partial so that if someone tries to cache the product partial it would throw an ActionView::Template::Error.

After

{% highlight ruby %}

<%= uncacheable! %> <%= product.title %> <%= product.description %> <%= image_tag(generate_presigned_url(product.image_url)) %> {% endhighlight %}

which would result in

{% highlight ruby %}

  ActionView::Template::Error (can't be fragment cached):
    1: <tr>
    2:     <%= uncacheable! %>
    3:   <td><%= product.title %></td>
    4:   <td><%= product.description %></td>
    5:   <td><%= image_tag(generate_presigned_url(product.image_url)) %></td>
  
  app/views/products/_product.html.erb:2

{% endhighlight %}

we can also use the caching? helper to check whether the current code path is being cached or to enforce caching.

{% highlight ruby %}

<%= raise Exception.new "This partial needs to be cached" unless caching? %> <%= product.title %> <%= product.description %> {% endhighlight %}

For more discussion related to this change, please refer to this PR.
